case_name: State of Punjab v. Sodhi Sukhdev Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 337 of 1960 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 19, 1960, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revision No. 596 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 337 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 19, 1960, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Revision No. 596 of 1959.

facts.text: The suit was filed by the respondent against the appellant on May 5, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been brought to this Court by special leave granted by this Court, and it arises from a suit filed by the respondent against the appellant on May 5, 1958.

facts.text: The respondent was a District and Sessions Judge in the erstwhile State of Pepsu.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent was a District and Sessions Judge in the erstwhile State of Pepsu.

facts.text: The respondent was removed from service on April 7, 1953, by an order passed by the President of India.

anchor.surface_text: He was removed from service on April 7, 1953, by an order passed by the President of India who was then in charge of the administration of the said State.

facts.text: The respondent made a representation on May 18, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then made a representation on May 18, 1955.

facts.text: The Council of Ministers considered the representation on September 28, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: This representation was considered by the Council of Ministers of the said State on September 28, 1955,

facts.text: The Council invited the advice of the Public Service Commission before taking action.

anchor.surface_text: but before taking any action it invited the advice of the Public Service Commission.

facts.text: The Council considered the representation again on March 8, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving the said advice the Council again considered the said representation on March 8, 1956,

facts.text: The Council considered the representation finally on August 11, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Finally, on August 11, 1956, the representation was considered over again by the Council,

facts.text: An order was passed to re-employ the respondent on some suitable post, communicated to him.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the said conclusion an order was passed which was communicated to the respondent. The order read thus Reference his representation dated the 18th May, 1955, against the order of his removal from service the State Government have ordered that he may be re-employed on some suitable post .

facts.text: Respondent filed suit claiming declaration that removal on April 7, 1953 was illegal and arrears of Rs. 62,700-6-0.

anchor.surface_text: After this order was communicated to him the respondent filed the present suit against the appellant and claimed a declaration, inter alia, that his removal from service on April 7, 1953, was illegal, void and inoperative and prayed for the recovery of Rs. 62,700-6-0 as arrears of his salary.

facts.text: Appellant disputed the respondent's claim on several grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant disputed the respondents claim on several grounds.

facts.text: Issues were framed by the trial judge on January 27, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Issues were accordingly framed by the trial judge on January 27, 1959.

facts.text: Respondent filed application under O.14 r.4 and O.11 r.14 CPC for production of documents.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile the respondent had filed an application under O. 14, r. 4 as well as O. 11, r. 14 of the Civil Procedure Code for the production of documents mentioned in the list annexed to the application.

facts.text: Trial court issued notice to appellant for production of documents.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court issued notice against the appellant for the production of the said documents.

facts.text: Mr. E. N. Mangat Rai, Chief Secretary, made affidavit claiming privilege under s.123 Evidence Act for certain documents.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to the notice Mr. E. N. Mangat Rai, Chief Secretary of the appellant, made an affidavit claiming privilege under s. 123 of the Act in respect of certain documents whose production had been ordered, and gave reasons in support of the claim.

facts.text: Trial court upheld privilege for some documents on August 27, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: After the affidavits had thus been filed by the parties the trial court heard their arguments on the question of privilege, and on August 27, 1959, it upheld the claim of privilege made by the appellant for the production of some documents,

facts.text: Respondent filed revision in Punjab High Court, C.R. 596 of 1959 under s.115 CPC and Art.227 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then moved the High Court of Punjab under s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure and Art. 227 of the Constitution for the quashing of the said order. The petition for revision  C. R. 596 of 1959  first came up for decision before D. K. Mahajan, J.,

facts.text: Mahajan J. referred the revision to larger bench Dulat and Dua JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judge took the view that the question raised by the petition was of considerable importance, and so he ordered that the papers should be placed before the learned Chief Justice to enable him to direct that the matter be decided by a larger Bench.

facts.text: Dulat and Dua JJ. reversed the trial court order in respect of four documents and directed production.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the petition was placed for decision before Dulat and Dua, JJ., who, after hearing the parties, reversed the order under revision in respect of four documents, and directed that the said documents be produced by the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant applied for certificate under Art.133, dismissed, then obtained special leave from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 133 but its application was dismissed. It then came to this Court and applied for and obtained special leave

facts.text: The four documents are: 1. Original order Pepsu Govt Sep 28, 1955 on representation May 18, 1955; 2. Original order Mar 8/9, 1956; 3. Original order Aug 11, 1956; 4. PSC Report.

anchor.surface_text: The documents of which discovery and inspection were claimed are thus described by the respondent Original order passed by Pepsu Government on September 28, 1955, on the representation dated May 18, 1955, submitted by Sodhi Sukhdev Singh Original order passed by the Pepsu Government

facts.text: Supreme Court held the documents relate to affairs of State under s.123 and privilege upheld.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the conclusion appears inescapable that the documents in question are protected under s. 123, and if the head of the department does not give permission for their production, the Court cannot compel the appellant to produce them.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 15, 1960 by Gajendragadkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 15. The judgment of B. P. Sinha, C. J., P. Gajendragadkar, J. and K. N. Wanchoo, J. was delivered by B. Gajendragadkar, J.

concepts.unlisted_description: State privilege for documents injurious to public interest

issues.text: What is the true scope and effect of sections 123 and 162 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, particularly regarding the respective roles of the court and the head of the department in claims of privilege for unpublished official records relating to affairs of State?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises for our decision a question of law of general importance under ss. 123 and 162 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872, hereafter called the Act . Originally the same point had been raised in another civil appeal before this Court, Civil Appeal No. 241 of 1955.

issues.text: Whether, having regard to the true scope and effect of sections 123 and 162 of the Act, the High Court was in error in refusing to uphold the claim of privilege raised by the appellant in respect of the documents in question?

anchor.surface_text: It then came to this Court and applied for and obtained special leave to challenge the validity of the order passed by the Punjab High Court and in the appeal the only question which has been urged before us is that having regard to the true scope and effect of the provisions of ss. 123 and 162 of the Act the High Court was in error in refusing to uphold the claim of privilege raised by the appellant in respect of the documents in question.

issues.text: Whether the court can determine the character of the document (whether it relates to affairs of State) or whether that is solely for the head of the department, and whether the court or the head decides if production would cause injury to public interest?

anchor.surface_text: It would thus be seen that on the point in controversy between the parties three views are possible. The first view is that it is the head of the department who decides to which class the document belongs if he comes to the conclusion that the document is innocuous he will give permission to its production if, however, he comes to the conclusion that the document is injurious he will withhold such permission in any case the Court does not materially come into the picture.

issues.text: Whether the four specific documents (orders of Pepsu Government/Cabinet and Public Service Commission report) relate to affairs of State and are protected under section 123?

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider whether the High Court was right in holding that the privilege claimed by the appellant in respect of the four documents in question was not justified, and that takes us to the consideration of the relevant facts in the present appeal. The documents of which discovery and inspection were claimed are thus described by the respondent...

issues.text: Whether the power of the court under Order 11 Rule 19(2) CPC to inspect documents for deciding validity of privilege claim is subject to the prohibition in section 162 of the Evidence Act?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri contended that the provisions of s. 162 can be invoked only where a witness has been summoned to produce a document and a privilege is claimed by him in respect of it... This position is seriously disputed by Mr. Seervai. The procedural law in regard to discovery, production and inspection of documents is contained in O. 11, rr. 12, 21.

arguments.claim: Sections 123 and 162 of the Evidence Act codify the English law on Crown privilege as it stood in 1872, where the head of the department has sole discretion to decide both whether the document relates to affairs of State and whether its production would injure public interest, leaving the court with no material role.

anchor.surface_text: It has, how ever, been very strenuously urged before us by Mr. J. Seervai that before proceeding to construe the said provisions it is necessary that the Court should bear in mind the historical background of the said provisions. His argument is that ss. 123 and 162 as they were enacted in the Act in 1872 were intended to introduce in India the English Law in regard to what is commonly described as the Crown privilege in the same form in which it obtained in England at the material time and so he has asked us to determine in the first instance what the true state of English Law was in or about 1872 A. D.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he document companytained orders is hardly relevant or material. The affidavits show what these documents purport to be and that leads to the inferenc

arguments.court_reasoning: Arguments break down in light of s.162 which empowers court to preliminary inquiry; position in India different from English law due to s.162.

arguments.claim: Affairs of State under s.123 should be narrowly construed to only include documents whose disclosure would cause injury to public interest, and the court should determine both the character and the injury.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it has been urged by Mr. Sastri that the expression documents relating to any affairs of State should receive a narrow construction and it should be confined only to the class of injurious documents. Even in regard to this class the argument is that the Court should decide the character of the document and should not hesitate to enquire, incidentally if necessary, whether its disclosure would lead to injury to public interest.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: arned judge appears to have company- strued s. 162 in the manner suggested by Mr. Seervai. In fact Mr. Seervais argument was that the companystruction

arguments.court_reasoning: Extreme position ignores discretion under s.123; court adopts harmonious construction instead.

arguments.claim: s.123 provides general prohibition against production of all documents relating to public business (affairs of State as genus), with head permitting only innocuous ones; court jurisdiction limited.

anchor.surface_text: Affairs of State , according to Mr. Seervai, are synonymous with public business and he contends that s. 123 provides for a general prohibition against the production of any document relating to public business unless permission for its production is given by the head of the department concerned.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 1  of s. 162, and also gives due effect to the discretion vested in the head of the department by s. 123. It would thus be clear that in view of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Affairs of State broad, includes classes for candour; but court determines character first.

arguments.claim: Court must determine whether document relates to affairs of State (preliminary character inquiry); head decides injury; harmonious reading of ss.123 & 162.

anchor.surface_text: Thus our conclusion is that reading ss.123 and 162 together the Court cannot hold an enquiry into the possible injury to public interest which may result from the disclosure of the document in question. That is a matter for the authority concerned to decide but the Court is competent, and indeed is bound, to hold a preliminary enquiry and determine the validity of the objections to its production, and that necessarily involves an enquiry into the question as to whether the evidence relates to an affair of State under s. 123 or not.

arguments.claim: Privilege claim must be by affidavit of Minister/Secretary, specifying consideration of each document, reasons for injury (briefly), not for litigation advantage.

anchor.surface_text: We think that in such cases the privilege should be claimed generally by the Minister in charge who is the political head of the department concerned if not, the Secretary of the department who is the departmental head should make the claim and the claim should always be made in the form of an affidavit.

arguments.claim: The four documents (Cabinet orders Sep28'55, Mar8/9'56, Aug11'56; PSC report) do not relate to affairs of State as per narrow definition (no injury to defence/diplomacy/public interest).

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with this question and in reversing the order passed by the trial court by which the privilege had been upheld, the High Court has purported to apply the definition of the expression affairs of State evolved by Khosla, J., as he then was, in the case of Governor-General in Council H. Peer Mohd. Khuda Bux Ors.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: sion, there is an end of the matter but, if he refuses, the party affected may take out necessary summons to the State Government to produce the docum

arguments.court_reasoning: Court does not inquire into injury; documents are Cabinet minutes/advice and PSC report, inherently affairs of State (Art.163(3)); High Court erred in inquiring injury and using non-exhaustive definition.

arguments.claim: The three 'original orders' by Pepsu Cabinet show provisional decisions to reinstate respondent, altering character.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Gopal Singh attempted to argue that before the final order was passed the Council of Ministers had decided to accept the respondents representation and to reinstate him, and that, according to him, the respondent seeks to prove by calling the two original orders.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a certificate which the minister has signed, stating what is necessary. I see numberharm in that procedure, provided it is understood that this is onl

arguments.court_reasoning: Provisional conclusions part of Council proceedings; open to reconsideration until final; still privileged.

arguments.claim: The four documents relate to affairs of State: Cabinet minutes/discussions/advice to Rajpramukh (saved by Art.163(3)), PSC report inherently privileged.

anchor.surface_text: Let us then consider whether the documents in question do really fall within the category of documents relating to affairs of State. Three of the documents the discovery of which the respondent claimed are described as original orders passed by the Pepsu Cabinet on the three respective dates.

arguments.claim: s.162 applies only when witness summoned to produce document; at discovery/inspection stage under O.11 r.19(2) CPC, court can inspect to decide privilege validity, not subject to s.162.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri contended that the provisions of s. 162 can be invoked only where a witness has been summoned to produce a document and a privilege is claimed by him in respect of it... This position is seriously disputed by Mr. Seervai.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ropositions  1  under s. 162 of the Evidence Act the companyrt has the overriding power to disallow a claim of privilege raised by the State in respec

arguments.court_reasoning: Procedural rules in O.11 subject to Evidence Act; s.162 governs validity of objections including at discovery stage.

arguments.claim: Chief Secretary's affidavits adequately support privilege claim under s.123.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to the notice Mr. E. N. Mangat Rai, Chief Secretary of the appellant, made an affidavit claiming privilege under s. 123 of the Act in respect of certain documents whose production had been ordered, and gave reasons in support of the claim.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , or might necessitate the attendance as witnesses or otherwise of officials who have pressing duties elsewhere  3  neither would it be good ground th

arguments.court_reasoning: Affidavits satisfy requirements laid down by court.

arguments.claim: Indian position differs from English law due to s.162 empowering court preliminary inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: It would thus be clear that in view of the provisions of s. 162 the position in India in regard to the Courts power and jurisdiction is different from the position under the English Law as it obtained in England in 1872.

arguments.claim: s.162 second clause covers objections to both production and admissibility; court can take collateral evidence instead of inspection for s.123 claims.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Court can take other evidence in lieu of inspection of the document in dealing with a privilege claimed or an objection raised even under s. 123. If the privileged document cannot be inspected the Court may well take other collateral evidence to determine its character or class.

arguments.claim: Affairs of State broadly include political/admin, defence, and documents affecting candour in policy-making (notes, minutes, reports).

anchor.surface_text: What are the affairs of State under s. 123 ? In the latter half of the Nineteenth Century affairs of State may have had a comparatively narrow content...

arguments.claim: Privilege not for defeating defence or litigation advantage, only genuine public injury.

anchor.surface_text: It must be clearly realised that the effect of the document on the ultimate course of litigation or its impact on the head of the department or the Minister in charge of the department, or even the government in power, has no relevance in making a claim for privilege under s.

holdings.text: Reading ss.123 and 162 together, the Court cannot hold an enquiry into the possible injury to public interest from disclosure of the document; that is for the head of the department, but the Court must hold a preliminary enquiry to determine if the document relates to affairs of State under s.123.

anchor.surface_text: Thus our conclusion is that reading ss.123 and 162 together the Court cannot hold an enquiry into the possible injury to public interest which may result from the disclosure of the document in question. That is a matter for the authority concerned to decide but the Court is competent, and indeed is bound, to hold a preliminary enquiry and determine the validity of the objections to its production, and that necessarily involves an enquiry into the question as to whether the evidence relates to an affair of State under s. 123 or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction reconciles s.123's discretion to head on injury with s.162's mandate for court to decide validity of objection, including document's character; rejects extreme views giving sole power to head or full power to court.

holdings.text: The Court has jurisdiction under s.162 to take collateral evidence but not inspect documents relating to affairs of State to determine their character.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Court can take other evidence in lieu of inspection of the document in dealing with a privilege claimed or an objection raised even under s. 123. If the privileged document cannot be inspected the Court may well take other collateral evidence to determine its character or class.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.162 cl.2 prohibits inspection for State matters but allows other evidence; applies to production objections as well as admissibility.

holdings.text: Privilege under s.123 must be claimed by affidavit of Minister or Secretary, showing each document considered, with brief reasons for apprehended public injury.

anchor.surface_text: We think that in such cases the privilege should be claimed generally by the Minister in charge who is the political head of the department concerned if not, the Secretary of the department who is the departmental head should make the claim and the claim should always be made in the form of an affidavit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ensures claim not for litigation advantage but genuine public interest; court may require Minister affidavit, cross-examination to test.

holdings.text: Affairs of State under s.123 are broadly construed to include political/administrative matters, defence, and documents like notes/minutes whose disclosure impairs candour in public policy.

anchor.surface_text: What are the affairs of State under s. 123 ? In the latter half of the Nineteenth Century affairs of State may have had a comparatively narrow content...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evolves with State functions; not straitjacket definition; includes classes protected for functioning of public service.

holdings.text: The four documents (Pepsu Cabinet orders Sep 28 1955, Mar 8/9 1956, Aug 11 1956; PSC report) relate to affairs of State as Cabinet minutes/advice (Art.163(3)) and PSC advice, protected under s.123.

anchor.surface_text: Let us then consider whether the documents in question do really fall within the category of documents relating to affairs of State. Three of the documents the discovery of which the respondent claimed are described as original orders passed by the Pepsu Cabinet on the three respective dates.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents embody Council discussions/provisional conclusions/advice to Rajpramukh; PSC report inherently privileged; provisional views part of proceedings.

holdings.text: The Punjab High Court erred in refusing to uphold privilege as it inquired into injury to public interest and applied non-exhaustive narrow definition of affairs of State.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that in dealing with the question of privilege raised under s. 123 it is not a part of the Courts jurisdiction to decide whether the disclosure of the given document would lead to any injury to public interest, that is a matter for the head of the department to consider and decide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court's role limited to character; High Court exceeded by assessing injury and using Khosla J's incomplete definition.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.162 apply at discovery/inspection stage under O.11 r.19(2) CPC; court cannot inspect documents for privilege validity if relating to State matters.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri contended that the provisions of s. 162 can be invoked only where a witness has been summoned to produce a document and a privilege is claimed by him in respect of it... The procedural law in regard to discovery, production and inspection of documents is contained in O. 11, rr. 12, 21.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural rules subject to Evidence Act; s.162 governs objections to production/admissibility including pre-trial stages.

holdings.text: Indian law under s.162 differs from English Crown privilege as in 1872; court has preliminary inquiry power on document character.

anchor.surface_text: It would thus be clear that in view of the provisions of s. 162 the position in India in regard to the Courts power and jurisdiction is different from the position under the English Law as it obtained in England in 1872.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.162 empowers court unlike English law; rejects historical argument based on drafting intent.

holdings.text: Chief Secretary's affidavits adequately support privilege claim under s.123.

anchor.surface_text: We should have stated that the two affidavits made by the Chief Secretary in support of the plea of the claim of privilege satisfied the requirements which we have laid down in our judgment, and no comment can be effectively made against them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavits meet standards for specificity and reasons; description confirms character.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that in dealing with the question of privilege raised under s. 123 it is not a part of the Courts jurisdiction to decide whether the disclosure of the given document would lead to any injury to public interest, that is a matter for the head of the department to consider and decide. We have also held that the preliminary enquiry where the character of the documents falls to be considered is within the jurisdiction and competence of the Court, and we have indicated how within the narrow limits prescribed by the second clause of s. 162 such an enquiry should be conducted. In view of this conclusion we must hold that the High Court was in error in trying to enquire into the consequences of the disclosure we may add that the decision of the High Court suffers from the additional infirmity that the said enquiry has been confined only to the specified classes of injury specified by Khosla, J., in his definition which cannot be treated as exhaustive. That being so, we think the appellant is justified in complaining against the validity of the decision of the High Court.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order directing production of four documents set aside; claim of privilege under ss. 123 and 162 Evidence Act upheld; documents relate to affairs of State and protected unless permission granted by head of department.
directions: Documents protected under s.123 unless head of department permits production. Affidavits by Chief Secretary satisfy requirements.

edges.explanation: The holding reading ss.123 and 162 together to assign no inquiry into injury to the court (but to the head) directly addresses the issue of their scope and respective roles.

anchor.surface_text: Thus our conclusion is that reading ss.123 and 162 together the Court cannot hold an enquiry into the possible injury to public interest which may result from the disclosure of the document in question. That is a matter for the authority concerned to decide but the Court is competent, and indeed is bound, to hold a preliminary enquiry and determine the validity of the objections to its production, and that necessarily involves an enquiry into the question as to whether the evidence relates to an affair of State under s. 123 or not.

edges.explanation: h1 interpretation of ss.123/162 prohibiting court enquiry into injury addresses i2 on High Court error under those sections
h1 clarifies court cannot inquire injury but implies role on character, addressing i3 on respective roles

anchor.surface_text: We have already held that in dealing with the question of privilege raised under s. 123 it is not a part of the Courts jurisdiction to decide whether the disclosure of the given document would lead to any injury to public interest, that is a matter for the head of the department to consider and decide. We have also held that the preliminary enquiry where the character of the documents falls to be considered is within the jurisdiction and competence of the Court, and we have indicated how within the narrow limits prescribed by the second clause of s. 162 such an enquiry should be conducted. In view of this conclusion we must hold that the High Court was in error in trying to enquire into the consequences of the disclosure we may add that the decision of the High Court suffers from the additional infirmity that the said enquiry has been confined only to the specified classes of injury specified by Khosla, J., in his definition which cannot be treated as exhaustive. That being so, we think the appellant is justified in complaining against the validity of the decision of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Court can take other evidence in lieu of inspection of the document in dealing with a privilege claimed or an objection raised even under s. 123. If the privileged document cannot be inspected the Court may well take other collateral evidence to determine its character or class.
